channel.title: Real IQ test
channel.description:
So I took a [b]real[/b] IQ test today and got 124.
i don't think that's bad o_O
anybody here know their iq?
don't make up one to make yourself look smart either, pl0x.

item.title: Real IQ test
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:28, topic:390284”][quote author=Davidi2 link=topic=486195.msg3564578#msg3564578 date=1302550088]
145 and over is considered genius. However, the chances that you have taken a real IQ test and got that score Wildy kingz, is low. IQ tests in general are inaccurate, but then to do it before you are even fully mentally developed is pointless, or even more inaccurate.
[/quote]
Eh, but who am I to talk? I only learn from textbooks that seemingly educated individuals write.[/quote]

Sometimes even educated authors don’t even know what they are talking about.

Read full topic

item.title: Real IQ test
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

rip4d:

All IQ really is is mental capacity… not intelligence overall. The higher your IQ, the more you can learn and retain.

IQ tests are meant to measure aptitude.

Wildy kingz:

im 13 years old and scored 149 i am considered a genius

Not even close.

Read full topic

So what your saying is Jc somebody should create a proper math integer for the formula.

item.title: Real IQ test
item.dc:creator: @noobs_are_ftw noobs are ftw
item.description:
@noobs_are_ftw wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:12, topic:390284”]An IQ test does not accurately represent one’s intellectual ability. There are 9 (known) types of intelligence.

http://skyview.vansd.org/lschmidt/Projects/The%20Nine%20Types%20of%20Intelligence.htm

For example, I may be “Number” smart, I am not “Nature” Smart.[/quote]

im exact opposite im nature smart but i suck at math lol

Read full topic

item.title: Real IQ test
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

If you ever took psychology or have common sense, you would know that IQ means nothing. IQ is calculated by dividing your mental age by your chronological age then multiplying by 100.

IQ = (MA/CA)*100

As you can see there is a huge flaw in this formula, if that. As your chronological age increases your mental age will either stay the same or decrease. When you’re 80 years old, your IQ may be a 30, well below mental retardation, which I believe is an IQ < 70. IQ tests are BS because of all the flaws…

…and as Zyle pointed out, the multiple intelligences theory (Gardner, I believe…?) argues that ‘intelligence’ is not quite as defined it could be on an IQ test. There are multiple types of intelligences; musical, interpersonal, intrapersonal, linguistic, kinesthetic, and others I can’t recall at the moment. You can be intelligent in one category and fail at the rest but still be considered intelligent. (Basketball players who aren’t school smart - kinesthetic, composers - musical, etc…)

@topic: I had an IQ of 154 when I took a legit IQ test when I was 14.

Read full topic

item.title: Real IQ test
item.dc:creator: @rip4d rip4d
item.description:
@rip4d wrote:

Well according to those 9 types of intelligence, I’m proficient in all of them

Last time my IQ was tested, I got a 148. In other words, I’m a legitimate genius

item.title: Real IQ test
item.dc:creator: @Loveandpower Loveandpower
item.description:
@Loveandpower wrote:

[quote=“Squirt Ltd, post:3, topic:390284”]130 when i was 13
does ur iq ever change? because im retarted now[/quote]Once you turn around 19-23 you start to lose the ability to reserve vasts amount of knowledge at once. That is why once you graduate high school people try to encourage a degree of some kind right away. That is also why many people have to study so much in college.

If you really think about it though, after age five you lose what is called plasticity. Plasticity in itself was a vast time in life where very large amounts of knowledge could be stored. There is an early development from 0-4 where you learn thousands upon thousands of words and life roles/lessons.

Read full topic
